metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of airborne WiDAS mission in the national observatory on climatology at Zhangye-Zhangye  flight zone on Jun. 29, 2008
metadata.description:
The dataset of airborne WiDAS mission was obtained in the national observatory on climatology at Zhangye-Zhangye flight zone on Jun. 29, 2008.
     Intra-band data available for general users include Level-2C data (after geometric, radiometric and atmospheric corrections), Level-1B browse image (after intra-band matching) and Level-2B browse image (after registration). The raw data, Level-1A, and data processing parameters were filed; applications would be evaluated prior to access. Data processing started in Aug. 2008 and ended in Apr. 2009, and in Nov. 2009, CCD data were reprocessed to adjust radiometric calibration. 
     The flying time of each route was as follows:

{|
! id
! flight
! relative height
! starttime
! endtime
! data size
! data state
! data quality
! ground targets 
|-
| 1 || 2#5 || 1500m || 13:14:39 || 13:22:43 || 122 || processed;complete || good || National observatory on climatology at Zhangye;Gulou in Zhangye 
|-
| 2 || 2#7 || 1500m || 13:28:23 || 13:35:31 || 108 || processed;complete || good
|-　 
| 3 || 2#9 || 1500m || 13:41:11 || 13:49:03 || 119 || processed;complete || good || wetland park in Zhangye
|}

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features and processing levels of data collected using airborne WiDAS sensors?
Feature Specification.Answer: geometric correction, radiometric calibration, atmospheric correction, Level-1B, Level-2B, Level-2C, Level-1A data, processing parameters archived

Quantification.Question: How many flight paths are included in a dataset acquired by an airborne WiDAS sensor over the specified area?

Definition.Question: What is the definition of 'Level-2C products' in the context of remote sensing data processing?
Definition.Answer: Level-2C products refer to data products that have undergone geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction, making them suitable for general user applications.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors could influence the need for multiple levels of data processing, such as geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction, in remote sensing data collection efforts?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for multiple levels of data processing, including geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction, in remote sensing data collection efforts could be influenced by the desire to ensure data accuracy and usability for various applications. Geometric correction is necessary to align the data spatially, radiometric calibration ensures that the sensor readings correspond to actual physical quantities, and atmospheric correction accounts for the effects of the atmosphere on the sensor data. These steps are essential in producing a Level-2C product that is suitable for general use, as seen in the data collection efforts for the airborne WiDAS sensor flights over the Zhangye flight district.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of implementing geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction on the quality and usability of aerial remote sensing data collected at approximately 1500 meters altitude?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction on aerial remote sensing data can lead to enhanced data quality and usability. These processes improve the accuracy of spatial positioning (geometric correction), ensure consistent brightness and color (radiometric calibration), and compensate for atmospheric conditions (atmospheric correction) that may alter data readings. As a result, the processed data can be more reliably used for various analyses, such as climate observation and urban planning, by providing clearer and more accurate representations of the observed areas, such as the Zhangye National Climate Observatory and other sites in Zhangye.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals of processing airborne WiDAS sensor data to Level-2C products, including geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goals of processing airborne WiDAS sensor data to Level-2C products, including geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction, are to provide accurate, reliable, and user-friendly data products for general users. This involves ensuring data quality by correcting for distortions and variability introduced during data acquisition, allowing for precise analysis and application in monitoring and studying various ground targets such as climate observatories and urban or wetland areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in preparing airborne sensor data for analysis, specifically focusing on geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction procedures?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data from the airborne WiDAS sensor undergoes several preprocessing steps before being released. The original data is first subjected to geometric correction, followed by radiometric calibration to ensure the accuracy of the sensor's readings. Finally, atmospheric correction is applied to account for the influence of the atmosphere on the captured data. The processed data is made available as Level-2C products, which include all these corrections, as well as Level-1B and Level-2B quick views with band-to-band registration. Original Level-1A data and processing parameters are archived and can be accessed upon request and approval.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the transformation of raw airborne sensor data into user-friendly data products in remote sensing applications?
Enablement.Answer: The transformation of raw airborne sensor data into user-friendly data products involves several processing techniques, including geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction. These processes lead to the creation of Level-2C products that are geometrically corrected, radiometrically calibrated, and atmospherically corrected, as well as quick-look images for Level-1B and Level-2B data. Original Level-1A data and processing parameters are archived and require approval for access.
